skill.name: statistical-analysis
skill.description: Guided statistical analysis with test selection and reporting. Use when you need help choosing appropriate tests for your data, assumption checking, power analysis, and APA-formatted results. Best for academic research reporting, test selection guidance. For implementing specific models programmatically use statsmodels.
skill.summary: Guided statistical analysis with test selection and reporting. Use when you need help choosing appro...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 190 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The 'external_commands' detections are Python code examples in markdown documentation blocks (not shell execution). The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' detections are triggered by common words like 'comprehensive' in documentation text at line 3 of markdown files. The 'system reconnaissance' detections flag statistical terms like ACF/PACF (Autocorrelation Function). This is a legitimate statistical analysis documentation skill with no security risks.

content.user_title: Analyze data with statistical tests and APA reporting
content.value_statement: Stop guessing which statistical test to use. Get guided test selection, assumption checking, and APA-formatted results for your research data. Perfect for students and researchers who need rigorous statistical analysis.
actual_capabilities: Recommends appropriate statistical tests based on data characteristics
Checks statistical assumptions with visualizations and formal tests
Calculates effect sizes and performs power analyses
Generates APA-style statistical reports with proper formatting
Provides both parametric and non-parametric test alternatives
limitations: Does not perform actual data analysis - provides guidance and code examples only
Requires user to have basic understanding of their data structure
Statistical recommendations are general - domain-specific considerations may apply
Code examples use Python libraries (scipy, statsmodels, matplotlib)

use_cases.title: Select statistical tests for thesis data
use_cases.description: Get help choosing the right tests, checking assumptions, and writing APA-style results sections for your dissertation or thesis.

use_cases.title: Validate analysis plan before conducting study
use_cases.description: Plan your statistical analysis strategy, determine sample sizes with power analysis, and ensure appropriate test selection for grant proposals.

use_cases.title: Learn proper statistical testing workflow
use_cases.description: Follow guided workflows to understand when to use t-tests vs ANOVA vs non-parametric alternatives with assumption checking.

prompt_templates.title: Choose the right test
prompt_templates.scenario: I have two groups to compare
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to compare test scores between students who received tutoring vs those who didn't. I have 30 students in each group. Which statistical test should I use and what assumptions do I need to check?

prompt_templates.title: Check assumptions
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm planning to run a one-way ANOVA with 4 groups. How do I check normality and homogeneity of variance assumptions? Show me the code and how to interpret results.

prompt_templates.title: Report results APA style
prompt_templates.prompt: I ran an independent t-test and got t(58) = 2.34, p = .022, with means of 78.5 (SD = 8.2) and 72.1 (SD = 9.5). Write this in proper APA format with effect size.

prompt_templates.title: Power analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to detect a medium effect size (Cohen's d = 0.5) with 80% power for an independent t-test at alpha = .05. How many participants do I need per group?

output_examples.input: I want to compare anxiety levels between therapy group and control group. Which test should I use?
output: Normality: Use Shapiro-Wilk test (n < 50) or visual inspection (n > 50)
Homogeneity of variance: Use Levene's test
Scale type: Continuous dependent variable required
If assumptions violated: Use Welch's t-test (if only homogeneity violated) or Mann-Whitney U test (if normality violated)
Effect size: Calculate Cohen's d with 95% CI

output_examples.input: How do I report an ANOVA result in APA format?
output: F(df_between, df_within) = F-value, p = p-value, partial eta-squared = value
Report means and standard deviations for each group in a table
Include a figure if helpful for visualization
Interpret: There was a significant effect of the independent variable

best_practices: Always check assumptions before interpreting test results - never skip this step
Report effect sizes with confidence intervals, not just p-values
Use visual inspection for normality with large samples (n > 100) as formal tests become overly sensitive
anti_patterns: Choosing tests based on desired outcomes rather than data characteristics
Reporting only p-values without effect sizes or confidence intervals
Assuming normality without checking, especially with small samples

faq.question: What is the difference between parametric and non-parametric tests?
faq.answer: Parametric tests assume specific distributions (usually normal) and equal variances. Non-parametric tests make fewer assumptions but may have less power. Use parametric when assumptions are met.

faq.question: How do I know if my data is normally distributed?
faq.answer: Use both visual (Q-Q plots, histograms) and formal tests (Shapiro-Wilk). With n > 30, mild violations are usually acceptable due to the Central Limit Theorem.

faq.question: What if my data violates multiple assumptions?
faq.answer: Consider data transformations (log, square root), use robust alternatives (Welch's test), or switch to non-parametric tests. Document all violations and remedies.

faq.question: How do I report statistical results in APA format?
faq.answer: Include test statistic, degrees of freedom, p-value, and effect size: t(58) = 2.34, p = .022, d = 0.61. Always report confidence intervals for effect sizes.

faq.question: When should I use Bayesian statistics?
faq.answer: Bayesian methods are useful when you have prior information, want to quantify evidence strength (Bayes Factors), or need to update beliefs as data accumulates.

faq.question: What is the minimum sample size I need?
faq.answer: Conduct a power analysis before data collection. For medium effects and 80% power, you typically need 25-35 per group for t-tests. Larger samples needed for smaller effects.
